segments.text: Okay, we're on.
Could you give a biographical background of your situation in Vietnam, such as your outfit duration, when you were drafted, etc.?
Okay, I was drafted in, my name is Bob Corbett, and I live in St. Paul.
My dad is a veteran of World War I and World War II, and I was drafted in October of 68.
And I ended up going through the infantry school at Fort Benning and arriving in Vietnam in early September of 1969.
And I was assigned to Charlie Company, 2nd of the 27th Wolfhound, a unit inside the 25th Division.
We were headquartered at Cu Chi, and I spent most of my time
The first half of the year in the field with the Charlie Company out near Hard Spot, Harris, Firebase, Jackson, near the Cambodian border.
And the last half, the last portion, five months I spent on top of the mountains that we bought then, the Black Virgin just outside of Tainan, inside Tainan Province.
And that's significant because it was the only elevation, the only relief spot in the area, in that whole South Vietnam area.
And so it was used by strategic communications.
And messages that were broadcast from the Pentagon by radio across Europe and retransmitted down through Turkey came in to the mountains because the rest of the area, as I said, was flat.
And it was kind of the key communication point.
They were relayed through a different series of steps to us, and then we relayed them down to Saigon to the military command headquarters.
Okay, Bob?
Yeah.
We'll get to more of that, the strategic and the location, a little later on in the interview.
Okay.
Just, let's see.
Okay, so you were, you said you were on the Cambodian border, is that correct?
Yeah.
Okay, how old were you when you were over there?
I was 23 when I was drafted.
Well, I guess I was 23 when I was over there.
Okay.
And you were there for, how long was the duration?
11 months.
11 months.
And I know you were wounded.
How long were you in the field and then how long, I guess, on the hill?
I was wounded the first time in the field.
I had been there probably 45 days in the field, so I've been in country.
It must have been about the first or second of November.
And then the second time was the 10th of September.
Okay.
Now, what was your rank in...
the people that you were serving with, fighting with?
I was an E-5, a Bucs sergeant, and when I arrived there, and my status was to be a squad sergeant, and after a series of attritions, people that
Zero set of countries in a time that expired or were injured and had to be fed back the wage.
When I left, I was acting.
Okay.
And how long were you the platoon leader then?
It's probably three and a half weeks, almost a month.
Okay.
Um, before we get into the Ho Chi Minh Trail itself, um, I guess I'm going to hit you with this objective question.
I might throw one in mixing with the objective.
Before you went, right prior to going to Nam, what was your attitude?
I mean, were you, let's say, maybe gun-ho, removed, or how, what were you feeling?
I wasn't done cold, but yet I wasn't pacifistic about it.
My feelings were that we were there because the people who were making the political decisions and the military decisions thought it was in our best interest.

and i believed in the democratic process and uh trusted that that that we were there for good reason okay um okay let's move on to the ho chi minh trail and please speak a little louder too okay um in your initial briefings what were you told that the ho chi minh trail was there have been so many different descriptions of it from

being just a single path to wide enough areas of flat road where two trucks could pass abreast and maybe petroleum lines feeding into the battlefield and someone suggested that even they he estimated that 90 000 troops traveled out a year to the nbn um what were you told it was in your briefings before you were there or were you told uh yeah we were we were told that it was uh
the main communication travel way of troop supplies and information from North Vietnam to South Vietnam.

And that pretty much, as you've described, is that at some point they were able to drive trucks up and down it, and at other points it was less well-defined and just an area that infiltration occurred through.
Okay.
Now, is this what you saw or is this what you were told?
This is what I was told.
Okay.
And how did that compare to what you saw when you actually went out there?

Um, I, I know that, uh, the Highway 1 was supposed to be, uh, the Ho Chi Minh Trail, and I was on Highway 1, and, uh, I, I know that we pulled an awful lot of ambushes that night, and, uh, that traffic at night was prohibitive.
That all seems to me, uh...
were required to be indoors during all the hours of darkness, and that anyone who was not indoors in the hours of darkness was considered to be a North Vietnamese or a Viet Cong.
And I don't know, I never pulled the ambush on the highway part, but I do know that down at the southern end, closer to Cambodia and Saigon,
where Cambodia is closest to Saigon, and it was just a trail.
Okay.
And, okay, now Highway 1, that is in Vietnam, correct?
Correct.
Okay.
They've also described it as, well, it overlaps into Cambodia, too.
Now, is that true, or what do you think?
Yeah, it does.
I think that it was down in the area that we were in, which was about 50 miles from Saigon, northwest of Saigon, on the Cambodian border.
It was not Highway 1.
Highway 1 ran somewhere.
into Cambodia and down into the Taigan.
But the infiltration, because of the heavy troop concentration, the heavy American troop concentration, the infiltration through the jungle and less well-traveled groups.
Okay.
And does that imply... Well, let's see.
You went into Cambodia also, correct?
Correct.
The trail was supposed to be there, too.
It depended when they would veer into Vietnam and at what point.
Is it pretty much what you find there?
A fairly well fortified North Vietnamese position and evidence of massive troops.
Anything else you want to say on that?
Well, just that prior to the Cambodian invasion, during the 1970s,
Our unit had been operating along that border, and we were ordered not to go into Cambodia.
We were told that if we had traded to Cambodia, we wouldn't be supported by our artillery gunners.
But that area was reconnoitered by the military.
five planes at night using infrared sensing devices.
And it was also reconned to some degree by American burps, long range patrols that would wander in to areas where there had been sightings.
Okay, so at that time, you knew it was just a matter of time before the invasion of Cambodia then.
Is that right?
I didn't.
I had hoped that that was the case, but I didn't know that it was the case.

I knew that the entire time that I was there, and for the period of time that the people who had been in my unit when I arrived, who had been in countries for, say, even 11 months, they knew that there were Viet Congs in North Carolina.
troops over there that used that area as a staging area, as a hospital area, as a fire area, and that we weren't authorized to get at them.
And we didn't really know that that is what was going to occur.

We thought that we were going over there, we were going to be a small unit, we would draw their fire, and then the commanders would request special permission to send in gunships into Cambodia, into these areas.
But you've got to go in to rescue these small units of Americans.
That's what we thought was going on.
We hoped that we would be able at some point to go in and have a more direct confrontation because we thought it would eliminate a lot of the problems that we experienced on a day-to-day basis.
Okay.
Well, then moving on to the strategy.
What were your orders and how were you ordered to stop the flow specifically?
Or have you pretty much covered that with what you just said?
Well, generally we were on a circuit destroy mission.
We would, if you would start the day, say at 7 o'clock on any morning, we would get ready and have chow and we'd start to move out through the jungle.
We'd spend most of the afternoon until about 3, 3.30 in the afternoon.
moving through an area in the jungle that had already been targeted by headquarters, or we had wanted to go to an escape headquarters in Google,
to go into and look around.
And our objective was if we went in and looked around today, we may want to come back that night or the following night and set up an ambush because we thought there was activity.
And we would do that, come back for the heat of the afternoon, try and be back in the face of the environment.
Generally preparing ourselves, resting a little bit.
And...

getting ready to go out on ambush patrol that night then that evening we would either go to that area or if we wanted to be a little more stealthy we'd go to another area that we'd reconned today or a couple of days three days prior and we set up an ambush along the trail outside a village wherever we thought that it was evident or wherever headquarters and intelligence
and we set up an ambush in hopes to catch them coming through.
Okay, and now this was in Cambodia?
This was in Vietnam.
Okay, close to the border?
Close to the border.
Okay, and to what degree do you think this strategy worked?
At certain times it was fairly effective because it was a big area to cover, and we were in blocking towards...
uh attempting to prevent the olympia from sending troops through cambodia to the closest point
to Saigon, we were blocking that closest point of Cambodia.
And it depended, if we'd established a pattern, they'd recognize that we were basically setting up ambushes within a true five-mile area along the border.
It didn't take them very long.
They'd start going outside that area and establishing their pipelines, moving their troops and flying them.

and once we realized that they pretty much figured out that we were ambushed in a particular area, and that this other area was not being covered by any of the American troops, and we pulled in there, usually at that point, there would be an enormous amount of contact for a couple days, and then they'd figure out some other routes that would fly without contact.
Okay.
Um, Bob, I'd like to pause at this point and just rewind and make sure everything's being recorded here, okay?
Good.
Okay, um, Bob, I'll need you to talk a little louder.
This recording really is not coming through too well.
Okay, I'll try my best.
Alright, thank you.
The enemy has often been described as being everywhere and nowhere at the same time.

Now, was there anything that would let you know whether the usual sniping harassment fire from nowhere would remain just that, or was there something that would tell you sometime that this firepower from nowhere would soon be from everywhere?
You know, was there something that you could let you know to differentiate between the usual harassment, or maybe that you were going to be in an engagement for a while?
No, not really.
You know, a rifle shot in the night is a rifle shot.

And ordinarily, if you heard one and within three or four seconds you just hear a barrage of them, it pretty generally indicated that you were not up against a large field unit because in those instances where they surrounded us and fired on us, it was a well-coordinated effort.
At exactly 12 o'clock on one occasion, they tore into us.
And I heard one round, and within a night, probably less than within a second, they opened up with machine guns and mortars, and they were right on us.
The whole world switched to rock and roll, and everything around us started to dance.
Wow.
And...
That's kind of how they were.
They didn't tie into you unless they were very confident that they could destroy you so seriously damaged that you weren't going to be real successful at any retaliation.
And then they'd move out of the area before our gunship or artillery could pin them down.
That's pretty much the basic, well,
Yeah, it was.
And, you know, in those instances where we would see them coming, it was extremely effective because we could either choose to hope that our positions would be undetected
and let them pass through us.
If, for example, since we operate primarily in 8- or 10-net groups, if there were too many of them, we didn't want to take that much of a chance, say if we saw 40 or 50.
Or it appears that the way that they were coming through the wood line out onto the rice paddies, that there may well be 40 or 50.
We would just let them go beyond us, be in radio communication and have gunships and additional troops ready and artillery.
And then at some point when we thought it was advantageous for us, we'd call in the artillery and try and have the gunships who pulled the horizon on them.
And then maybe we'd open up on the conditions that we thought we could use.
When we saw them, it was a good deal.
When they saw us, and I'm sure that they saw us a lot more than we were ever aware of, when they saw us, they didn't think they could handle us.
They just let us go.
I'd like to move to the technology of the war, but right before that, do you think that you were well-equipped or maybe over-equipped to get the job done?

um in terms of having military power we could we were probably over equipped we could have gotten the job done with less military power with with fewer m16s or you know we didn't need more explosive weapons we had we had uh very adequate weapons uh the technological aspect was certainly on our side compared to what they had we generally we controlled the air
And we had long range artillery, which up north they had, but they weren't able to set up very effectively down south.
And we probably had more sophisticated communications, which would have played a key role.
OK. And specifically, did your platoon get to seeing new technological innovations?
Well, we used the M16, which the Vietnam War started out with the M14 as the primary weapon.
The M16 wasn't adopted by the military until some point after Vietnam had been going on for a couple of years.
We used the duper, which fires grenades that hit 50 meters.
It was extremely effective.
It was like a big shot gun.
It was called duper because when it went off, it was a duper.
Even that's what it sounded like.
They used whatever weapons they could capture for us.
They also had an extremely effective AK.
The AK is more of a long-range weapon than the M4P.
The M4P was designed to be light, to be maneuverable, and to quickly pump out.
on a cyclical rate of fire, if you hooked it up in such a way as you would a machine gun, the M16 on automatic would fire 800 to 850 rounds per minute, which is a very fast rate of fire.
And it's light, and it fires smaller, and requires lighter ammunition.
And their AK, however, was more accurate over a greater distance.
Bob, on this recording, I'm sure you're making sure that your...
I guess your mouth is in the best position for the receiver.
Well, I think so.
Okay.
Just to concentrate on that, and maybe a little bit louder, too.
Okay.
Okay.
Went out on the trail, and I put that in quotes.
I really... Would you agree that there's really no specific trail, but just a...
a term for the mass movement that was going on.
I agree.
Okay.
Okay, we went out on the trail.
Were there any signs of our other strategies that were being used on the trail?
For example, we had electronic sensors and, of course, massive bombing from B-52s and then defoliation from Agent Orange.
Did you see any signs of maybe these other strategies?
Every day, every day, we were constantly concerned with booby traps.
And the majority of the booby traps were either mortars or grenades or artillery rounds which did explode upon impact or were taken from overran American units.
and they were stuck in such a way with a trip wire or a device, a grenade would be placed underneath an artillery shell, and O.P.
started nosing around the artillery shell and moved it.
The lieutenant had pulled in the grenade, and so the handle would flop loose, and then the grenade would explode, and it would cause the artillery shell to explode.
You know, those kind of ingenious things.
Now, are you saying those were American-made?
I would say that a majority of booby-trapped devices were American-made.
The North Vietnamese or the VCs had rigged other things, too, so that they would explode upon impact.
Or when you happened to pull a vine that was connected to the device, you could pull the handle free from a grenade.
In terms of the B-52 and some of these other methods, there's an argument saying that they in actuality were ineffective in that they increased the will of the people to resist.
Now, was there any way that you could elaborate on that if you were able to witness that?
Is that true?
I don't know that they increased the will of the people to resist.
I think they...
that at various points it will seem to be higher and lower.
And I really don't know what effect the B-52 had on Bouchard, other than that perhaps the same effect that a Russian plane cruising down our street might have on us, versus a less visible presence.
I don't know.
Yeah, sort of a terror factor.
Yeah.
Yeah.
All right, well, let's move on to the relationship with your fellow men there.
What do you think about the leadership?
Well, not really what do you think, but how were they as far as competency, consistency, and their concern for the troops?
I think that in general the leadership, the personnel who comprised the leadership were probably extremely competent people.
I think that it's probably fairly well discussed and or even documented that there was a stifling effect.
The military hierarchy

acted in such a way as to stifle true and valid observations from the lower ranks from the people actually out the grunts during the day-to-day combat they stifled uh and changed and modified the information that these people put in and discouraged them from uh from those above them to insist on the truth they weren't able to get the truth across to the elite
And I think the leaders wanted the troops who could best fight the war or do anything, exist on a day-to-day basis with the troops.
Well, we don't want Colonel so-and-so to think that we're not performing well, so we're going to tell him this or we're going to tell him that because that's what he wants to hear.
There are many examples of people in leadership positions who did not do that, but there does seem to be some kind of generalization that's true.
That sounds like the recent Westmoreland case.
I think that's probably the...
the most verified account of stifling gas.
And it hurt us all.
It hurt us all.
Because when I arrived there in September of 1969, two or three weeks after I was there, I began to believe that this was not working.

that what I read in Stars and Stripes was a military newspaper which was published on a daily basis in Vietnam, and we would occasionally get out in the fields about a week late and maybe two or three a week.
What they told us was going on, you begin to distrust it.
You begin to know that a lot of it was propaganda.
You resented the fact that you, the grunt, actually conducted the war, had to sort through this information and wonder, is this true or is that true?
Because you would see instances of actions that you were involved in that you didn't consider the reporting to be true.
Yeah.
Wow.
And, well, the overall effect on morale?
Yeah, I think that the overall effect of the... You know, the...
what are you going to do, send me to Nam attitude.
It doesn't make any difference attitude.
Kind of came out because we conducted the war with our hands tied while we stocked it up with records, which eventually, which prevented us from winning the war.
What about
You refer to doctoring up the records.
In Phil Caputo's book, A Rumor of War, he talks about the whole idea of body count, that the upper echelons wanted to see results.
and not necessarily the accurate one.
How do you measure a war that is really hard to measure?
This wasn't a linear war.
There wasn't one solid front.
And the whole emphasis on body count, wasn't that sort of demoralizing?
Yeah, I think it was.
I think the only way you can really picture a war is the morale of the troops in the area.
If you get down with the grunts, what do you think?
Are you keeping this area clean?
What's your attitude?
Are you going out and stopping the infiltration?
Are you preventing the VT and the communists from harassing the people in the villages?
When you go to the villages, when you're passing through the peasants, are they happy to see you?

uh that gives you an idea of uh of who's in charge who's in power but uh simply saying well my predecessor here had uh they had uh five uh five an average of five feet killed per night in this area and uh therefore i as battalion commander had better
At best, top that, I'd better have an average of six.
You know, that kind of attitude doesn't clearly indicate to anyone.
All it does is say, yeah, gee, we're doing better than we were before, and therefore we must be winning.
And as a result, there's very little serious discussion entertained by higher-ups as to how to more effectively conduct a war.
And that hurt me.
Well, it's almost all these little factors that are mutually reciprocating and reinforcing to get this whole cycle, which seems to have a pretty bad effect from what you're saying.
That's a good point.
They did feed into each other, and they were self-fulfilling processes.
Once you start lying about how well you're doing in one particular area...

And another battalion commander decides that he better lie to come up with better figures because somebody he's competing with for the rank of colonel, when someone is doing his job in another area, is claiming to do it better by these methods.
Pretty soon, nobody really knows what the truth is, and I'm afraid that to a large measure that happens.
You know, being squad leader, as you were for some while, that made you probably more aware of some of the command decisions and choice decisions.
Is there anything that sticks out or stuck out in your mind at the time as just being totally ridiculous and, you know, you would have recommended something else or not?

Well, I can think of many instances where we would be briefed by the, when I first came in country, we'd be briefed by the platoon leader who had just come from a briefing by the captain who had just been listening to the radio and the battalion commander had been telling him what his mission for the day is or what his mission for

the weekend, like what areas we moved to, the word eventually came on down to us that we would be telling the men that we would be going to this location, these forts, and on the map setting up an ambush.
And we may have known, we may have been by that area before.
We may have known that where they were putting us was into an indefensible position, or we could better spend our time over here.
But the...
The response when we would say, we don't want to go here, this is a bad position because with only 10 of us, we can't defend it.
It's open for this area.
We've had, you know, we know, we've had contact before.
Intelligence says that there's this large unit, you know, of BSBs, Viet Cong, only two miles away over here, and we know that they're probably going to infiltrate through this area.
We should really have a company or at least a platoon in this area.
When we say those kind of things, generally the response was, these are what you're going to start.
You're in the military.
This is the way it goes.
You will do this.
Are you saying that at times you were sent out less than a platoon strength?
We generally were sent out less than platoon strength.
We generally went out in 8 to 10 man units.
Wow.
You must have been correlated somewhere.
Yeah.
The platoon would be out in three or four sections of eight to ten men.
And we would know where we were.
We would know what frequency we were at.
And we would be at a certain distance from each other so that our fire, if we had the fire, that it wouldn't catch any of our pieces.
and the attempt was to maximize, make as thin a debris as possible over this area so that when the fuel pump came in or out, we had the greatest likelihood of making contact.
And then the theory was that once we made contact, we'd assume that they had a larger unit, but we would be able to move
gunships would always be the first to reach us.
And then, uh, uh, following the gunships was the troop ships and additional troops.
Hmm.
And, uh, then we'd rush in larger troops that would set up behind them, and we would try to catch them between our 10-man units and the larger troops.
Okay.
Um, in your platoon, how big was your platoon?
Uh, we were, we probably operated generally from 28 to 32 men.
That is somewhat understrength, isn't it?
Well, it's ideally equal to 40.
But it was pretty much the average.
I doubt that we ever had over 32 in any time.
I wonder if Nixon had started his decimization, excuse me, problem or solution, did that have anything to do with the smaller numbers or was it just because of lack of troops overall?
It was because of lack of troops overall.
People were injured.
People would be wounded.

People would develop foot rots, would catch malaria, and they'd have to go back into the rear and possibly went to the hospital in Saigon or Tokyo, or else they were going on leave, or their time in the country had expired, or they would have come in to get out of the field.
so that we have a better job.
Are you familiar with the term bragging?
Yes.
Was that evident?
I know it increased as the anti-war movement increased back on the home front, but was that a present?
Did you see that, or did that happen while you were there?
Any incidents?
Well, I really am not certain.
There...
A little louder, please.
Mm-hmm.

had decided that he knew everything about the war and how to be a platoon leader before he arrived there, and he wouldn't listen to any of the troops who'd been around a while, the message was given to him that that is not a healthy way to go.
And he was injured at one point, but it's not entirely clear
Whether it was Charlie's fire or us.
Okay.
Within your platoon, Bob, was there an overriding sense of camaraderie?
Or was there more of a... Did the soldiers tend to form groups, even, you know, on the off-patrol duty time?
There was, groups were formed, but there was an overriding sense of camaraderie.
That cut through everything.
You knew that you had to be on your best terms, that you had to trust everyone that was around you, and they had to depend on you.
And it was my experience that that was by far and away the overriding attitude.
Did this transcend any of the perhaps
racist issues that were still a problem in the U.S. during the time.
Was there much racism that you saw within the platoons and in the Army in general?
Within the Army in general, I thought there was a great deal of racism.
Within the platoons, within the company, out in the field, I really can't think of an incident where it was an issue.
But when we came back in to stand down after being out in the field for about 52 days, there were some name-calling and shoving based on race.
Wow.
But once back in Tennessee, these were not between the members of a similar platoon.
They were between members of different platoons.
But out in the field, it never surfaced, and in our platoon, it was never an issue during the time I was there.
Okay.
Let's see here.
Now, you were sent after the Tet Offenses.
That's right.
Okay, and you knew that the anti-war movement was already in process, and the time you left, was that any effect on the troops as far as morale?
Or did you even hear much of it once you were out there, of the growing anti-war movement?
Well, we would hear about it because everyone, you know, received a lot of letters.
And my aunt, Tita, had a subscription of the Minneapolis Star that said,
And so about once every 10 days or so, I would leave either 10 papers, and I'd read about it there.
And the Stars and Stripes, the military magazine, paper, sailing paper in Vietnam, downplayed it.
The radio station downplayed it or brought up absurd circumstances that would occur.
It wasn't...
To me personally, and to those in my squad and platoon that I was closest to, I don't really think we were demoralized exactly.
I think a lot of the general attitude was that we weren't getting the job done.
And the reason we weren't getting the job done is because we couldn't go into Cambodia.
And we couldn't go up north.

If we could go up north, if we wanted to win the war, we could have bombed the geysers, bombed the industrial centers, bombed the supply of troops coming from North Vietnamese troops coming down south.
And we could have done it.
It would have been eradicating a great deal of North Vietnamese and many more South Vietnamese.
But we could have won the war that way.
I'm still sticking with the morale theme.

Do you think the whole policy of search and destroy, with its implication that eventually everyone was going to have to assume that point position, do you think, did that sort of have a negative effect in itself on the troop morale?
Just knowing that you're out there mainly to draw fire, if you're out there on the point.
And hopefully you will survive that and be able to fire back.
It did.
It did.
But, you know, it did because we knew that there existed a large number of sanctuaries in Cambodia and North Vietnam that we couldn't go after.

And at the point where we knew that we couldn't go after and conduct the war, at that point it seemed so treacherous and foolhardy for us to be there and for the military to be using our bodies in this way of drawing fire so that we could...

We gained body count when very few of the people in my platoon and no one in my original squad believed that we would ever win the war, that we would do anything other than, we never believed that the South Vietnamese would defend themselves against the North Vietnamese.
We didn't think they were capable.
And we never believed that anything other than withdrawal by American forces
would occur down the road.
And that was demoralizing because it seems foolish to take the chance on risking our lives when our real objective was not to win the war.
Yeah, so that sign is probably...
the key morale demoralizer?
I think it was.
I think it was the primary attitude of most American GIs.
Certainly of the American GIs that I encountered.
You mentioned the Vietnamese.
Now, did you fight alongside with Arvin?
We did.
We had, it was called a sister company of ours, who had a base about a quarter of a mile away from our base.
And because they would indiscriminately get fire up, fire toward our base, thinking that there were being seen between our base and theirs.

uh we had to had to have them move farther away and uh it was it was interesting because they had uh their wives and uh some of their families that would live with them in this state and uh they pulled they seemed to pull very few ambush controls that night

aggressive they wanted to be as close to us as they could they did very little and when we we'd be out in the jungle sometimes and we'd be able to watch them at a distance across the clearing through a starlight scope at night they'd be uh they'd be either disoriented or unaware that we were there and uh and should have been aware that we were there because uh you know
They, to a certain degree, I can appreciate their attitude.
They've been at war forever with most of these people throughout their lifetimes.
And war was something that they were trying to survive.
And they weren't as aggressive as troops.
They weren't as dependable.
And they didn't believe that they would ever win the war.
That if the world was going to be won, it was going to be won by us.
Do you think they really cared?
I don't know whether they...
I think...
I mean, which side won?
Yeah, I don't know.
That's...
I don't know how to answer that.
Oh, well, yeah.
I guess I should move on from that anyway.
That's a very good question.
Okay.
Now, how about with your relationship with the Vietnamese civilians?
Did you encounter them frequently?
Can I answer the previous question by saying that, yes, I think they cared, and they wanted their side, our side, to win.

But they decided that from having been at war all their life, that they were better off to be a survivor in a communist regime than they were to be a dead capitalist or dead in a more ideal situation.
Okay.
Would you give me a brief on that last question again?
Sure.
Okay.
